articles.headline: The High Price of Creating Free Ads
articles.snippet: Companies that have invited consumers to create advertising often find it to be stressful, costly and time-consuming.
articles.abstract: Companies that have invited consumers to create advertising often find it to be stressful, costly and time-consuming.
articles.lead_paragraph: From an advertiser’s perspective, it sounds so easy: invite the public to create commercials for your brand, hold a contest to pick the best one and sit back while average Americans do the creative work.

articles.headline: Speaking Up in Fresh Air at Home Depot
articles.snippet: The chain’s new chief executive was everything his predecessor was not: folksy, sincere, occasionally funny and often self-deprecating.
articles.abstract: The chain’s new chief executive was everything his predecessor was not: folksy, sincere, occasionally funny and often self-deprecating.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dirty little secret of this year’s Home Depot annual meeting were the timers.

articles.headline: Coke Takes $4 Billion Step Away From Carbonation
articles.snippet: The Glacéau deal offered evidence that coming up with a new beverage, or putting a new twist on an old one, can be lucrative.
articles.abstract: The Glacéau deal offered evidence that coming up with a new beverage, or putting a new twist on an old one, can be lucrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you set up a lemonade stand this weekend, you might consider stirring in something a little different.

articles.headline: Test of Drug for Diabetes in Jeopardy
articles.snippet: Some of the 4,450 patients enrolled in a large clinical study have dropped out because of safety concerns about Avandia.
articles.abstract: Some of the 4,450 patients enrolled in a large clinical study have dropped out because of safety concerns about Avandia.
articles.lead_paragraph: A large clinical study meant to test the heart safety of the diabetes treatment Avandia may be in jeopardy as a result of recent reports of the drug’s risks, according to an executive for its maker, GlaxoSmithKline.

articles.headline: Official Fired by Wal-Mart Fights Back
articles.snippet: Julie Roehm, an ousted advertising executive, asserted that several top Wal-Mart officers violated the company’s strict ethics policies.
articles.abstract: Julie Roehm, an ousted advertising executive, asserted that several top Wal-Mart officers violated the company’s strict ethics policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Wal-Mart Stores fired a top advertising executive, Julie Roehm, six months ago, the company accused her of violating a wide range of its strict ethics policies.

articles.headline: And Gas Saver Makes Three Cars in the Driveway
articles.snippet: Thousands of consumers are lining up to buy small cars, but they are not giving up their S.U.V.’s and pickups.
articles.abstract: Thousands of consumers are lining up to buy small cars, but they are not giving up their S.U.V.’s and pickups.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, May 25 — With gas prices well over $3 a gallon nationwide, many drivers are lining up to buy small cars.

articles.headline: A Quiet Revolution in Algeria: Gains by Women
articles.snippet: In a tradition-bound nation, women are emerging as an economic and political force unheard of in the rest of the Arab world.
articles.abstract: In a tradition-bound nation, women are emerging as an economic and political force unheard of in the rest of the Arab world.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALGIERS, May 25 — In this tradition-bound nation scarred by a brutal Islamist-led civil war that killed more than 100,000, a quiet revolution is under way: women are emerging as an economic and political force unheard of in the rest of the Arab world.

articles.headline: Suit Sheds Light on Clintons’ Ties to a Benefactor
articles.snippet: Details have emerged about the relationship of former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton with Vinod Gupta, the founder of infoUSA.
articles.abstract: Details have emerged about the relationship of former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton with Vinod Gupta, the founder of infoUSA.
articles.lead_paragraph: When former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took a family vacation in January 2002 to Acapulco, Mexico, one of their longtime supporters, Vinod Gupta, provided his company’s private jet to fly them there.

articles.headline: Strife Foreseen in Iraq Exit, but Experts Split on Degree
articles.snippet: There is fear of a violent chain reaction should U.S. troops withdraw, but opinions differ as to how bad things would get.
articles.abstract: There is fear of a violent chain reaction should U.S. troops withdraw, but opinions differ as to how bad things would get.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26 — There is one matter on which American military commanders, many Iraqis and some of the Bush administration’s staunchest Congressional critics agree: if the United States withdrew its forces from Baghdad’s streets this fall, the murder and mayhem would increase.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Victim of Climate Change, a Town Seeks a Lifeline
articles.snippet: The permanently frozen subsoil, known as permafrost, upon which many Native Alaskan villages rest is melting.
articles.abstract: The permanently frozen subsoil, known as permafrost, upon which many Native Alaskan villages rest is melting.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWTOK, Alaska — The sturdy little Cessnas land whenever the fog lifts, delivering children’s bicycles, boxes of bullets, outboard motors and cans of dried oats. And then, with a rumble down a gravel strip, the planes are gone, the outside world recedes and this subarctic outpost steels itself once again to face the frontier of climate change.

articles.headline: Coke Struggles to Keep Up With Nimble Rivals
articles.snippet: As its rivals have diversified and taken risks, the Coca-Cola Company has struggled to reinvent itself.
articles.abstract: As its rivals have diversified and taken risks, the Coca-Cola Company has struggled to reinvent itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: “A Coke is a Coke and no amount of money can get you a better Coke than the one the bum on the corner is drinking. All the Cokes are the same and all the Cokes are good.” — Andy Warhol

articles.headline: The Invitation That Isn’t in the Mail
articles.snippet: Shareholders of Sunrise Senior Living may have been eager to hear from their company’s executives and board this year, but no meeting has been scheduled.
articles.abstract: Shareholders of Sunrise Senior Living may have been eager to hear from their company’s executives and board this year, but no meeting has been scheduled.
articles.lead_paragraph: INVESTORS who attend annual shareholder meetings — ritualistic though the gatherings usually are — often do so to catch a glimpse of management and directors and to hear how their companies are faring.

articles.headline: In Fierce Competition, Google Finds Novel Ways to Feed Hiring Machine
articles.snippet: Pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests are meant to create excitement around a company and impress potential recruits as young as college freshmen.
articles.abstract: Pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests are meant to create excitement around a company and impress potential recruits as young as college freshmen.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — On a spring Saturday, about 90 students from Stanford and as many from the University of California, Berkeley, converged on Google’s corporate campus for a day of spirited team competition over mind-bending puzzles, Lego building problems and video games.

articles.headline: Militants Widen Reach as Terror Seeps Out of Iraq
articles.snippet: The Iraq war, which for years has drawn militants from around the world, is beginning to export fighters and tactics to neighboring countries and beyond.
articles.abstract: The Iraq war, which for years has drawn militants from around the world, is beginning to export fighters and tactics to neighboring countries and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Muhammad al-Darsi got out of prison in Libya last year after serving time for militant activities, he had one goal: killing Americans in Iraq.
articles.byline: By Michael Moss and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: At BET, Fighting the Rerun
articles.snippet: Despite being the largest African-American cable channel, BET has developed few of its own marketable stars and virtually no breakout programs.
articles.abstract: Despite being the largest African-American cable channel, BET has developed few of its own marketable stars and virtually no breakout programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, executives from Black Entertainment Television walked through the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, laying out the plans for the annual BET Music Awards on June 26. The broadcast has become the highest-rated award show on cable, topping the MTV Music Awards, ESPN’s ESPY Awards and the Nickelodeon Kids’ Choice Awards.

articles.headline: NBC Said to Be in Talks to Remove Program Chief
articles.snippet: NBC Universal is in talks to sever its ties with Kevin Reilly, several executives said Sunday.
articles.abstract: NBC Universal is in talks to sever its ties with Kevin Reilly, several executives said Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC Universal is in talks to sever its ties with Kevin Reilly, the president of its entertainment division and the network’s chief programmer, just three months after extending his contract for three years, several executives informed of the discussions said yesterday.

articles.headline: Wealthy Enclave Offers Windfall for Candidates
articles.snippet: Awash in money from hedge funds, Greenwich, Conn., has joined New York, Los Angeles and Silicon Valley as must stops on the 2008 fund-raising tour.
articles.abstract: Awash in money from hedge funds, Greenwich, Conn., has joined New York, Los Angeles and Silicon Valley as must stops on the 2008 fund-raising tour.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENWICH, Conn., May 25 — Senator John McCain made his pitch to this gilded shoreline suburb back in April. Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts came on May 7, followed one night later by former President Bill Clinton on behalf of his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Last weekend, it was back-to-back appearances by Senator Barack Obama, topped off on Sunday with a visit from Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor.

articles.headline: Not to See the Fallen Is No Favor
articles.snippet: While troop numbers are surging, the media that cover them are leaking away, worn out by the danger and expense of covering a war that refuses to end.
articles.abstract: While troop numbers are surging, the media that cover them are leaking away, worn out by the danger and expense of covering a war that refuses to end.
articles.lead_paragraph: On this Memorial Day, thousands of United States men and women are engaged in untold acts of bravery and drudgery on behalf of what our leaders have defined as vital American interests in Iraq and Afghanistan.

articles.headline: As Allies Turn Foe, Disillusion Rises in Some G.I.’s
articles.snippet: In interviews with more than a dozen soldiers, most said they were disillusioned by the situation in Iraq.
articles.abstract: In interviews with more than a dozen soldiers, most said they were disillusioned by the situation in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Staff Sgt. David Safstrom does not regret his previous tours in Iraq, not even a difficult second stint when two comrades were killed while trying to capture insurgents.

articles.headline: OMG! Cute Boys, Kissing Tips and Lots of Pics, as Magazines Find a Niche
articles.snippet: With a faithful audience in the millions, magazines for the early teenage years are in overdrive.
articles.abstract: With a faithful audience in the millions, magazines for the early teenage years are in overdrive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Above the neon-orange lettering that promotes the issue’s “love blogs” and other content, Zac, Corbin and Miley smile winningly on the cover for the May/June issue of J-14.
